рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ржпрж╝ ржЖржЗрж╕рж┐ржЯрж┐ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░рзЗрж░ рж╕ржорж╕рзНржпрж╛ ржУ рж╕ржорж╛ржзрж╛ржи

рж╕ржорж╕рзНржпрж╛рж╕ржорзВрж╣

  1. ржЕржмржХрж╛ржарж╛ржорзЛржЧржд ржЕржкрж░рзНржпрж╛ржкрзНрждрждрж╛: рж╕ржХрж▓ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ржкрзНрж░рждрж┐рж╖рзНржарж╛ржирзЗ ржкрж░рзНржпрж╛ржкрзНржд ржХржорзНржкрж┐ржЙржЯрж╛рж░, ржорж╛рж▓рзНржЯрж┐ржорж┐ржбрж┐рзЯрж╛ рж╕рж░ржЮрзНржЬрж╛ржо, ржжрзНрж░рзБрждржЧрждрж┐рж░ ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░ржирзЗржЯ ржПржмржВ ржирж┐рж░ржмржЪрзНржЫрж┐ржирзНржи ржмрж┐ржжрзНржпрзБрзО рж╕рж░ржмрж░рж╛рж╣рзЗрж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржмред
  2. ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржмрзИрж╖ржорзНржп (Digital Divide): рж╕ржХрж▓ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛рж░рзНржерзАрж░, ржмрж┐рж╢рзЗрж╖ ржХрж░рзЗ ржЧрзНрж░рж╛ржорзАржг ржУ рж╕рзБржмрж┐ржзрж╛ржмржЮрзНржЪрж┐ржд ржкрж░рж┐ржмрж╛рж░рзЗрж░, ржкрзНрж░ржпрж╝рзЛржЬржирзАржпрж╝ ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржбрж┐ржнрж╛ржЗрж╕ (рж╕рзНржорж╛рж░рзНржЯржлрзЛржи/ржХржорзНржкрж┐ржЙржЯрж╛рж░) ржУ ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░ржирзЗржЯ ржХрзЗржирж╛рж░ рж╕рж╛ржорж░рзНржерзНржпрзЗрж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржмред
  3. рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржжржХрзНрж╖рждрж╛ ржУ ржорж╛ржирж╕рж┐ржХрждрж╛рж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржм: ржЖржЗрж╕рж┐ржЯрж┐ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░рзЗ рж╕ржХрж▓ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХрзЗрж░ ржкрзНрж░ржпрж╝рзЛржЬржирзАржпрж╝ ржкрзНрж░рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржг, ржжржХрзНрж╖рждрж╛ ржУ ржЗрждрж┐ржмрж╛ржЪржХ ржорж╛ржирж╕рж┐ржХрждрж╛рж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржмред ржЕржирзЗржХрзЗ ржкрзНрж░ржпрзБржХрзНрждрж┐ржХрзЗ ржЕрждрж┐рж░рж┐ржХрзНржд ржмрзЛржЭрж╛ ржоржирзЗ ржХрж░рзЗржиред
  4. ржорж╛ржирж╕ржорзНржоржд ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржХржиржЯрзЗржирзНржЯрзЗрж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржм: ржЬрж╛рждрзАржпрж╝ ржкрж╛ржарзНржпржХрзНрж░ржо ржЕржирзБржпрж╛ржпрж╝рзА рж╕ржХрж▓ ржмрж┐рж╖ржпрж╝рзЗрж░ ржЬржирзНржп рж╕рзНржерж╛ржирзАржпрж╝ ржнрж╛рж╖рж╛ржпрж╝ ржорж╛ржирж╕ржорзНржоржд, ржЖржХрж░рзНрж╖ржгрзАржпрж╝ ржУ ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░рзЗржХрзНржЯрж┐ржн ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ ржЙржкржХрж░ржгрзЗрж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржмред
  5. ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ржЧрж░рж┐ рж╕рж╣рж╛ржпрж╝рждрж╛ ржУ рж░ржХрзНрж╖ржгрж╛ржмрзЗржХрзНрж╖ржгрзЗрж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржм: рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ржкрзНрж░рждрж┐рж╖рзНржарж╛ржирзЗ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рзГржд ржЖржЗрж╕рж┐ржЯрж┐ рж╕рж░ржЮрзНржЬрж╛ржо ржирж╖рзНржЯ рж╣рж▓рзЗ рждрж╛ ржжрзНрж░рзБржд ржорзЗрж░рж╛ржоржд ржмрж╛ рж░ржХрзНрж╖ржгрж╛ржмрзЗржХрзНрж╖ржгрзЗрж░ ржЬржирзНржп ржжржХрзНрж╖ ржЬржиржмрж▓рзЗрж░ ржЕржнрж╛ржмред

рж╕ржорж╛ржзрж╛ржи

  1. ржЕржмржХрж╛ржарж╛ржорзЛ ржЙржирзНржиржпрж╝ржи: рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ ржУ ржмрзЗрж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ ржЙржжрзНржпрзЛржЧрзЗ ржкрж░рзНржпрж╛ржпрж╝ржХрзНрж░ржорзЗ рж╕ржХрж▓ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ржкрзНрж░рждрж┐рж╖рзНржарж╛ржирзЗ ржЖржЗрж╕рж┐ржЯрж┐ ржЕржмржХрж╛ржарж╛ржорзЛ ржирж┐рж╢рзНржЪрж┐ржд ржХрж░рж╛ ржПржмржВ рж░ржХрзНрж╖ржгрж╛ржмрзЗржХрзНрж╖ржгрзЗрж░ ржЬржирзНржп ржмрж░рж╛ржжрзНржж ржкрзНрж░ржжрж╛ржиред
  2. ржзрж╛рж░рж╛ржмрж╛рж╣рж┐ржХ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХ ржкрзНрж░рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржг: рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржЬржирзНржп ржХрж╛рж░рзНржпржХрж░, ржмрж╛рж╕рзНрждржмржнрж┐рждрзНрждрж┐ржХ ржУ ржзрж╛рж░рж╛ржмрж╛рж╣рж┐ржХ ржкрзНрж░рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржгрзЗрж░ ржЖржпрж╝рзЛржЬржи ржХрж░рж╛ ржПржмржВ рждрж╛ржжрзЗрж░ ржкрзЗрж╢рж╛ржЧржд ржЙржирзНржиржпрж╝ржирзЗ ржкрзНрж░ржгрзЛржжржирж╛ ржкрзНрж░ржжрж╛ржиред
  3. ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржХржиржЯрзЗржирзНржЯ ржЙржирзНржиржпрж╝ржи: рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ ржЙржжрзНржпрзЛржЧрзЗ ржПржмржВ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржЕржВрж╢ржЧрзНрж░рж╣ржгрзЗ ржорж╛ржирж╕ржорзНржоржд ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржХржиржЯрзЗржирзНржЯ рждрзИрж░рж┐рж░ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржХрж╛ржарж╛ржорзЛржмржжрзНржз ржкрж░рж┐ржХрж▓рзНржкржирж╛ ржЧрзНрж░рж╣ржг ржУ ржмрж╛рж╕рзНрждржмрж╛ржпрж╝ржи ржХрж░рж╛ред
  4. ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ржЧрж░рж┐ рж╕рж╣рж╛ржпрж╝рждрж╛ ржХрзЗржирзНржжрзНрж░ рж╕рзНржерж╛ржкржи: ржкрзНрж░рждрж┐ржЯрж┐ ржЙржкржЬрзЗрж▓рж╛ржпрж╝ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржХрж░рзЗ 'ржЖржЗрж╕рж┐ржЯрж┐ рж░рж┐рж╕рзЛрж░рзНрж╕ ржУ рж╕рж╛ржкрзЛрж░рзНржЯ рж╕рзЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░' рж╕рзНржерж╛ржкржи ржХрж░рж╛, ржпрзЗржЦрж╛ржи ржерзЗржХрзЗ ржмрж┐ржжрзНржпрж╛рж▓ржпрж╝ржЧрзБрж▓рзЛ ржирж┐ржпрж╝ржорж┐ржд ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ржЧрж░рж┐ рж╕рзЗржмрж╛ ржкрж╛ржмрзЗред
  5. рж╕ржЪрзЗрждржирждрж╛ ржУ ржЕржВрж╢рзАржжрж╛рж░рж┐рждрзНржм ржмрзГржжрзНржзрж┐: ржЖржЗрж╕рж┐ржЯрж┐рж░ рж╕рзБржлрж▓ рж╕ржорзНржкрж░рзНржХрзЗ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХ, рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛рж░рзНржерзА, ржЕржнрж┐ржнрж╛ржмржХ ржУ рж╕рзНржХрзБрж▓ ржмрзНржпржмрж╕рзНржерж╛ржкржирж╛ ржХржорж┐ржЯрж┐ржХрзЗ рж╕ржЪрзЗрждржи ржХрж░рж╛ ржПржмржВ ржПрж░ рж╕ржлрж▓ ржмрж╛рж╕рзНрждржмрж╛ржпрж╝ржирзЗ рж╕ржХрж▓рзЗрж░ ржЕржВрж╢рзАржжрж╛рж░рж┐рждрзНржм ржирж┐рж╢рзНржЪрж┐ржд ржХрж░рж╛ред

ржнрж╛рж░рзНржЪрзБржпрж╝рж╛рж▓ ржХрзНрж▓рж╛рж╕рж░рзБржо рж╣рж▓рзЛ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржЕржирж▓рж╛ржЗржи рж╢рж┐ржЦржи ржкрж░рж┐ржмрзЗрж╢ ржпрзЗржЦрж╛ржирзЗ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХ ржУ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛рж░рзНржерзАрж░рж╛ ржнрзМржЧрзЛрж▓рж┐ржХржнрж╛ржмрзЗ ржнрж┐ржирзНржи ржнрж┐ржирзНржи рж╕рзНржерж╛ржирзЗ ржЕржмрж╕рзНржерж╛ржи ржХрж░рзЗржУ ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░ржирзЗржЯрзЗрж░ ржорж╛ржзрзНржпржорзЗ ржПржХржЯрж┐ рж╕рж╛ржзрж╛рж░ржг рж╕ржлржЯржУржпрж╝рзНржпрж╛рж░ ржмрж╛ ржкрзНрж▓рзНржпрж╛ржЯржлрж░рзНржорзЗ ржПржХрждрзНрж░рж┐ржд рж╣ржпрж╝рзЗ рж░рж┐ржпрж╝рзЗрж▓-ржЯрж╛ржЗржорзЗ (рж╕рж░рж╛рж╕рж░рж┐) ржкрж╛ржаржжрж╛ржи ржХрж╛рж░рзНржпржХрзНрж░ржорзЗ ржЕржВрж╢ ржирж┐рждрзЗ ржкрж╛рж░рзЗред ржПржЦрж╛ржирзЗ ржнрж┐ржбрж┐ржУ ржХржиржлрж╛рж░рзЗржирзНрж╕рж┐ржВ, ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░рзЗржХрзНржЯрж┐ржн ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ рж╣рзЛржпрж╝рж╛ржЗржЯржмрзЛрж░рзНржб, рж╕рзНржХрзНрж░рж┐ржи рж╢рзЗржпрж╝рж╛рж░рж┐ржВ, ржЪрзНржпрж╛ржЯрж┐ржВ, ржлрж╛ржЗрж▓ рж╢рзЗржпрж╝рж╛рж░рж┐ржВ ржПржмржВ ржХрзНрж▓рж╛рж╕ рж░рзЗржХрж░рзНржбрж┐ржВ ржХрж░рж╛рж░ ржорждрзЛ рж╕рзБржмрж┐ржзрж╛ ржерж╛ржХрзЗ, ржпрж╛ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржмрж╛рж╕рзНрждржм рж╢рзНрж░рзЗржгрж┐ржХржХрзНрж╖рзЗрж░ ржорждрзЛржЗ ржорж┐ржерж╕рзНржХрзНрж░рж┐ржпрж╝рж╛рж░ рж╕рзБржпрзЛржЧ ржкрзНрж░ржжрж╛ржи ржХрж░рзЗред ржЬрзБржо (Zoom), ржЧрзБржЧрж▓ ржорж┐ржЯ (Google Meet), ржорж╛ржЗржХрзНрж░рзЛрж╕ржлржЯ ржЯрж┐ржорж╕ (Microsoft Teams) ржЗрждрзНржпрж╛ржжрж┐ ржЬржиржкрзНрж░рж┐ржпрж╝ ржнрж╛рж░рзНржЪрзБржпрж╝рж╛рж▓ ржХрзНрж▓рж╛рж╕рж░рзБржо рж╕ржлржЯржУржпрж╝рзНржпрж╛рж░ред ржПржЯрж┐ ржжрзВрж░рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржг (Distance Learning) ржПржмржВ ржЕржирж▓рж╛ржЗржи рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛рж░ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржЕржкрж░рж┐рж╣рж╛рж░рзНржп ржЙржкрж╛ржжрж╛ржиред

рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХ ржмрж╛рждрж╛ржпрж╝ржи рж╣рж▓рзЛ ржЧржгржкрзНрж░ржЬрж╛рждржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржмрж╛ржВрж▓рж╛ржжрзЗрж╢ рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рзЗрж░ a2i (Aspire to Innovate) ржкрзНрж░ржХрж▓рзНржкрзЗрж░ ржЕржзрзАржирзЗ ржкрж░рж┐ржЪрж╛рж▓рж┐ржд рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржЬржирзНржп ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржЕржирж▓рж╛ржЗржи ржкрзНрж▓рзНржпрж╛ржЯржлрж░рзНржо ржмрж╛ ржУржпрж╝рзЗржм ржкрзЛрж░рзНржЯрж╛рж▓ (www.teachers.gov.bd)ред ржПржЯрж┐ ржорзВрж▓ржд ржмрж╛ржВрж▓рж╛ржжрзЗрж╢рзЗрж░ рж╕рзНржХрзБрж▓, ржХрж▓рзЗржЬ ржУ ржорж╛ржжрзНрж░рж╛рж╕рж╛рж░ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржкрзЗрж╢рж╛ржЧржд рж╕рж╛ржорж╛ржЬрж┐ржХ ржпрзЛржЧрж╛ржпрзЛржЧ ржорж╛ржзрзНржпржо (Professional Social Network)ред ржПрж░ ржорзВрж▓ ржЙржжрзНржжрзЗрж╢рзНржп рж╣рж▓рзЛ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржоржзрзНржпрзЗ ржкрж╛рж░рж╕рзНржкрж░рж┐ржХ рж╕рж╣ржпрзЛржЧрж┐рждрж╛ ржмрзГржжрзНржзрж┐, ржкрзЗрж╢рж╛ржЧржд ржжржХрзНрж╖рждрж╛рж░ ржЙржирзНржиржпрж╝ржи ржПржмржВ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ржпрж╝ ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржХржиржЯрзЗржирзНржЯрзЗрж░ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░ржХрзЗ ржЙрзОрж╕рж╛рж╣рж┐ржд ржХрж░рж╛ред ржПржЦрж╛ржирзЗ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХрж░рж╛ ржирж┐ржЬрзЗржжрзЗрж░ рждрзИрж░рж┐ ржбрж┐ржЬрж┐ржЯрж╛рж▓ ржХржиржЯрзЗржирзНржЯ, ржкрзНрж░рзЗржЬрзЗржирзНржЯрзЗрж╢ржи, ржнрж┐ржбрж┐ржУ, ржЫржмрж┐ ржЗрждрзНржпрж╛ржжрж┐ ржЖржкрж▓рзЛржб ржУ рж╢рзЗржпрж╝рж╛рж░ ржХрж░рждрзЗ ржкрж╛рж░рзЗржи ржПржмржВ ржЕржирзНржпрзЗрж░ рждрзИрж░рж┐ рж▓ржХрзНрж╖ рж▓ржХрзНрж╖ ржХржиржЯрзЗржирзНржЯ ржбрж╛ржЙржирж▓рзЛржб ржХрж░рзЗ рж╢рзНрж░рзЗржгрж┐ржХржХрзНрж╖рзЗ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░ ржХрж░рждрзЗ ржкрж╛рж░рзЗржиред ржПржЯрж┐ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖ржХржжрзЗрж░ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржмрж┐рж╢рж╛рж▓ ржЕржирж▓рж╛ржЗржи ржкрзЗрж╢рж╛ржЧржд ржХржорж┐ржЙржирж┐ржЯрж┐ рж╣рж┐рж╕рзЗржмрзЗ ржХрж╛ржЬ ржХрж░рзЗред

ржХрзНрж▓рж╛ржЙржб ржХржорзНржкрж┐ржЙржЯрж┐ржВ рж╣рж▓рзЛ ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░ржирзЗржЯрзЗрж░ ржорж╛ржзрзНржпржорзЗ ржмрж┐ржнрж┐ржирзНржи ржХржорзНржкрж┐ржЙржЯрж┐ржВ рж╕рзЗржмрж╛ (ржпрзЗржоржи: рж╕рж╛рж░рзНржнрж╛рж░, рж╕рзНржЯрзЛрж░рзЗржЬ, ржбрзЗржЯрж╛ржмрзЗржЬ, рж╕ржлржЯржУржпрж╝рзНржпрж╛рж░)цМЙщЬАц▒В ржкрзНрж░ржжрж╛ржи ржХрж░рж╛рж░ ржПржХржЯрж┐ ржоржбрзЗрж▓ред ржПржЦрж╛ржирзЗ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░ржХрж╛рж░рзАржХрзЗ ржирж┐ржЬрзЗрж░ ржХржорзНржкрж┐ржЙржЯрж╛рж░рзЗ ржХрзЛржирзЛ ржмрзНржпржпрж╝ржмрж╣рзБрж▓ рж╕ржлржЯржУржпрж╝рзНржпрж╛рж░ ржЗржирж╕рзНржЯрж▓ ржмрж╛ ржбрзЗржЯрж╛ рж╕ржВрж░ржХрзНрж╖ржг ржирж╛ ржХрж░рзЗ, ржЗржирзНржЯрж╛рж░ржирзЗржЯрзЗрж░ ржорж╛ржзрзНржпржорзЗ ржжрзВрж░ржмрж░рзНрждрзА ржХрзЛржирзЛ рж╢ржХрзНрждрж┐рж╢рж╛рж▓рзА рж╕рж╛рж░рзНржнрж╛рж░рзЗ рждрж╛ рж╕ржВрж░ржХрзНрж╖ржг ржУ ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░ ржХрж░рж╛рж░ рж╕рзБржпрзЛржЧ ржжрзЗржУржпрж╝рж╛ рж╣ржпрж╝ред ржПрж░ рж╕ржмржЪрзЗржпрж╝рзЗ ржмржбрж╝ рж╕рзБржмрж┐ржзрж╛ рж╣рж▓рзЛ, ржмрзНржпржмрж╣рж╛рж░ржХрж╛рж░рзА ржпрзЗржХрзЛржирзЛ рж╕рзНржерж╛ржи ржерзЗржХрзЗ ржпрзЗржХрзЛржирзЛ ржбрж┐ржнрж╛ржЗрж╕ ржжрж┐ржпрж╝рзЗ рждрж╛рж░ ржбрзЗржЯрж╛ ржмрж╛ ржЕрзНржпрж╛ржкрзНрж▓рж┐ржХрзЗрж╢ржи ржЕрзНржпрж╛ржХрзНрж╕рзЗрж╕ ржХрж░рждрзЗ ржкрж╛рж░рзЗред ржЧрзБржЧрж▓ ржбрзНрж░рж╛ржЗржн, ржбрзНрж░ржкржмржХрзНрж╕, ржорж╛ржЗржХрзНрж░рзЛрж╕ржлржЯ ржУржпрж╝рж╛ржиржбрзНрж░рж╛ржЗржн ржХрзНрж▓рж╛ржЙржб рж╕рзНржЯрзЛрж░рзЗржЬрзЗрж░ ржЬржиржкрзНрж░рж┐ржпрж╝ ржЙржжрж╛рж╣рж░ржгред рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛ржХрзНрж╖рзЗрждрзНрж░рзЗ ржПржЯрж┐ ржлрж╛ржЗрж▓ рж╢рзЗржпрж╝рж╛рж░рж┐ржВ, рж╕рж╣ржпрзЛржЧрж┐рждрж╛ржорзВрж▓ржХ ржХрж╛ржЬ ржПржмржВ рж╢рж┐ржХрзНрж╖рж╛рж░рзНржерзАржжрзЗрж░ ржбрзЗржЯрж╛ рж╕рж╣ржЬрзЗ рж╕ржВрж░ржХрзНрж╖ржгрзЗрж░ ржЬржирзНржп ржЕрждрзНржпржирзНржд ржЧрзБрж░рзБрждрзНржмржкрзВрж░рзНржгред

labels: Poetry: Keats (Ode on a Grecian Urn)
Explain with Reference to the Context

written.q: 1. Which teaching method has been recommended for teaching English in the curriculum of Bangladesh? Compare Grammar-Translation method and Communicative Language Teaching method. Marks: 8
written.a:
Recommended Method and Comparison of Approaches

The teaching method recommended for English in the national curriculum of Bangladesh is the Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) approach. The main goal of adopting CLT is to develop students' communicative competence, enabling them to use English effectively in real-life situations, rather than just knowing theoretical rules about the language.

Comparison: Grammar-Translation Method (GTM) vs. Communicative Language Teaching (CLT)

Feature Grammar-Translation Method (GTM) Communicative Language Teaching (CLT)
Primary Goal To read classical literature and benefit from the mental discipline of learning a foreign language. To develop the ability to communicate effectively and appropriately in real-life situations.
Core Focus Focuses on explicit grammar rules, memorizing vocabulary, and translating texts. Focuses on communicating meaning, fluency, and using language appropriate for the context.
Skills Emphasized Primarily emphasizes reading and writing. Listening and speaking are neglected. Integrates all four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing from the beginning.
Teacher's Role The teacher is the ultimate authority and source of knowledge, correcting all errors. The teacher is a facilitator, guide, and co-communicator who creates situations for communication.
Student's Role Students are passive recipients of information, often working alone. Students are active participants who negotiate meaning and learn through interaction, often in pairs or groups.
Medium of Instruction The mother tongue (L1) is used extensively for explanations and instructions. The target language, English (L2), is predominantly used in the classroom.

written.q: 2. "The main idea of the Ode on a Grecian Urn is the mutability of life as contrasted with the immorality of the principle of beauty as expressed in art." -Discuss Keats as a poet of beauty in the light of this remark. Marks: 8
written.a:
Keats as a Poet of Beauty

John Keats is known as a poet of beauty, and the given remark about "Ode on a Grecian Urn" perfectly captures the core of his artistic philosophy. The poem masterfully contrasts the fleeting, transient nature of human life with the eternal, unchanging quality of beauty as immortalized by art.

The ode describes a series of scenes depicted on an ancient Greek urn. These moments of love, music, and ritual are frozen in time, made permanent by art:

  • The Lover and the Maiden: The lover can never actually kiss his beloved, but their love is saved from the decay of time. Their passion remains forever young, unlike mortal love which can fade.
  • The Piper: The musician's song is unheard, yet Keats calls it "sweeter" because it is eternalтАФa song for the spirit that never ends.
  • The Sacrificial Procession: The crowd heading to a sacrifice is captured forever in a moment of devotion.

This contrast between the "cold pastoral" of the urn and the warm but changing reality of human life leads Keats to a profound realization. For him, beauty is a way to understand a higher truth. The suffering of human life is transcended by the permanence of art. This idea is famously concluded in the urn's final lines:

'Beauty is truth, truth beauty,тАФthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.'

This statement suggests that the profound beauty found in art is the highest form of truth available to humanity. It offers comfort in a world of change and mortality, solidifying Keats's status as the ultimate poet of beauty.

written.q: 3. What romantic elements do you get from Shelley's "To a Skylark"? Marks: 8
written.a:
Romantic Elements in "To a Skylark"

Percy Bysshe Shelley's "To a Skylark" is a perfect example of a Romantic poem, as it embodies several key characteristics of the Romantic movement. The poem is more than a description of a bird; it is a profound celebration of nature, imagination, and emotion.

The main romantic elements in the poem are:

  • Glorification of Nature: The poem addresses the skylark, a creature of nature, as a "blithe Spirit." The bird is elevated to a symbol of pure, natural joy. For Romantics, nature was a source of spiritual truth.
  • Emphasis on Emotion and Imagination: The poet uses his imagination to compare the bird's song to a poet's hymns, a maiden's love song, and a glow-worm's light, expressing his emotional response rather than giving a scientific description.
  • The Ideal and the Supernatural: The skylark is idealized as a perfect being, a "scorner of the ground," free from human pain. Its song represents an ideal form of art and happiness that humans can only aspire to.
  • Focus on the Individual: The poem reflects the poet's individual experience. He deeply feels the contrast between the bird's pure joy and human suffering: "We look before and after, / And pine for what is not." He wishes to learn the bird's secret to create powerful art.
  • Vivid Imagery: Shelley uses rich, sensory imagery and brilliant metaphors to capture the essence of the unseen bird and its song, a hallmark of Romantic poetry.

written.q: 4. Discuss the guidelines of Francis Bacon according to the essay of "Parents and Children." Marks: 8
written.a:
Bacon's Guidelines in "Of Parents and Children"

In his essay "Of Parents and Children," Francis Bacon offers practical and worldly advice to parents on how to raise children effectively. His counsel characteristically advocates for a balanced approach, avoiding both excessive indulgence and excessive severity.

Bacon's key guidelines can be summarized as follows:

  • Balanced Affection: Parents should love their children, but with wisdom. He warns that spoiling children makes them insolent, while a lack of affection can crush their spirits.
  • Prudence with Money: Parents should be liberal with their children's allowances but should not give them too much financial freedom too early. This teaches them financial responsibility.
  • Be Impartial: Parents should treat all their children equitably. He advises against showing obvious favoritism, as it creates jealousy and conflict among siblings.
  • Encourage Natural Talents: Parents should observe their children's natural inclinations and guide them toward professions that suit their character. Forcing a child into an unsuitable career is a grave mistake.
  • Settle Children into a Career: Bacon advises parents to help their children choose and settle into a profession at an appropriate age to avoid an idle and unproductive life.
  • Recognize the Impact of Circumstance: Bacon notes that younger brothers, having less inheritance, often have to work harder and are therefore more likely to succeed than elder brothers who may become complacent.

Overall, Bacon's advice is timeless, emphasizing moderation, foresight, and a practical understanding of human nature in the complex task of parenting.

written.q: 5. (a) Write down the objectives of current National Curriculum for English in the secondary level. Marks: 4
written.a:
Objectives of the National Curriculum for English

The main objective of the current National Curriculum for English at the secondary level in Bangladesh is to develop students' communicative competence. The curriculum is designed to enable students to use English effectively for communication in both academic and real-life situations. The specific objectives focus on the integrated development of the four basic language skills:

  • Listening: To enable students to understand spoken English in various contexts, such as conversations, announcements, and instructions.
  • Speaking: To enable students to express themselves orally in English with reasonable fluency and accuracy in everyday situations.
  • Reading: To enable students to read and comprehend different types of texts (e.g., stories, articles, notices) for information and pleasure.
  • Writing: To enable students to write clearly in English for various purposes, such as composing paragraphs, letters, and emails.

written.q: (b) Short Note: (i) EFL
written.a:
(i) EFL (English as a Foreign Language)

EFL refers to the study of English in a non-English-speaking country where it is not the main language for daily life. In an EFL context, students typically learn English in a formal classroom setting but have limited opportunities to use it for communication outside. Bangladesh is a prime example of an EFL country.

written.q: Short Note: (ii) EGP
written.a:
(ii) EGP (English for General Purposes)

EGP refers to teaching English for general, non-specific, everyday communication. It is not tailored to a particular profession or academic field. EGP courses focus on the core language skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing) and foundational grammar and vocabulary needed for social interaction and travel. The English taught in most schools is a form of EGP.

written.q: Short Note: (iii) NCTB
written.a:
(iii) NCTB (National Curriculum and Textbook Board)

The NCTB is the autonomous government organization in Bangladesh responsible for developing, revising, and implementing the national curriculum for primary and secondary education. Its key functions also include writing, printing, and distributing textbooks for these levels free of cost. The NCTB plays a central role in the country's education system.

written.q: Short Note: (iv) Learning outcome.
written.a:
(iv) Learning Outcome

A learning outcome is a clear statement describing what a student is expected to know, understand, or be able to do as a result of a learning experience (like a lesson or course). It focuses on the result of learning, not the teaching process. For example: "By the end of the lesson, students will be able to write a paragraph describing their daily routine."

written.q: 6. Sketch the character of the protagonist of "An Astrologer's Day". Marks: 8
written.a:
Character Sketch of the Astrologer

The protagonist of R.K. Narayan's short story, "An Astrologer's Day," is a complex character who lives a life of deception rooted in a troubled past. He is not a real astrologer but a shrewd man who has mastered the art of reading human nature.

  • Shrewd and Perceptive: The astrologer's success comes from his keen observation of people, not from any knowledge of the stars. He understands common human problems and uses clever guesswork and ambiguous statements to appear wise.
  • Pragmatic and Hardworking: He is a practical man who adopted this fraudulent profession out of necessity to support his family. He works long hours every day, showing his diligence.
  • A Man with a Dark Past: The story reveals that he is a fugitive. In his youth, he stabbed a man named Guru Nayak, left him for dead, and fled his village. This forced him to abandon his old life and assume a new identity.
  • Burdened by Guilt: Despite his calm exterior, he carries the heavy psychological burden of believing he is a murderer. This is evident from the profound relief he feels when he learns that Guru Nayak is alive. His final confession to his wife, "a great load is gone from me today," reveals the deep anxiety he has lived with for years.

In essence, the astrologer is a fascinating blend of cunning and conscience. His entire life is an act to escape his past, but he ultimately finds peace not from his earnings, but from the unexpected relief from his greatest sin.

written.q: 7. Explain with reference to the context: (a) My little horse must think it queer To stop without a farmhouse near Between the woods and frozen lake The darkest evening of the year.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: These lines are from the second stanza of the famous poem "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening" by the American poet Robert Frost.

Context: The speaker, traveling by horse-drawn sleigh, has stopped unexpectedly to watch a secluded woods fill with snow. The location is isolated, far from any house, on the "darkest evening of the year."

Explanation: In these lines, the speaker imagines his horse's thoughts. The horse, a creature of habit and practicality, finds it strange ('queer') to stop without a clear purpose, like a farmhouse. The speaker's decision to pause simply to appreciate the quiet beauty of the dark woods is a uniquely human act of contemplation, which is foreign to the animal's practical world. This contrast highlights the pull between worldly duties and the quiet allure of nature.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (b) Teach me half the gladness That thy brain must know Such harmonious madness From my lips would flow The world should listen then-as I am listening now.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: These lines form the final stanza of the ode "To a Skylark" by the Romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelley.

Context: Throughout the poem, the poet has been listening in awe to the ecstatic song of a skylark. He has contrasted the bird's pure, unadulterated joy with the pain and sorrow inherent in the human condition. He feels the skylark holds a secret to happiness that eludes mankind.

Explanation: In this concluding plea, the poet directly asks the skylark to teach him even half of the pure gladness that inspires its song. He believes that if he could learn this secret, he would be able to create poetry so beautiful and powerful ("harmonious madness") that the entire world would be compelled to listen, just as he is now captivated by the bird's song. These lines powerfully convey the Romantic ideal of the poet as a seer and of nature as the ultimate source of divine inspiration.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (c) Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed and some few to be chewed and digested.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This famous aphoristic statement is from Francis Bacon's celebrated essay, "Of Studies."

Context: In the essay, Bacon discusses the purpose of study, the different ways people approach reading, and the effects of study on an individual's character. He argues that one should read with purpose and good judgment.

Explanation: Bacon uses a powerful metaphor, comparing the act of reading to eating, to categorize books and recommend different reading approaches.

  • "To be tasted" refers to books that do not need to be read completely. One can dip into them, reading parts here and there for a general idea.
  • "To be swallowed" refers to less important books that can be read quickly to grasp the main points without paying close attention to detail.
  • "To be chewed and digested" refers to the few truly great and important books. These must be read with diligence and full attention, so their ideas can be fully understood and integrated into one's own thinking, just as food is digested to provide nourishment.
This advice urges the reader to be selective and to adapt their reading strategy based on the quality and purpose of the book.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (d) He was as much a stranger to the stars, as are his innocent customers.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This line is from the opening section of R.K. Narayan's classic short story, "An Astrologer's Day."

Context: The narrator is introducing the protagonist, the astrologer, and describing his professional setup. He explains how the astrologer arranges his equipmentтАФcowrie shells, mystic chartsтАФto create an impressive atmosphere for his clients.

Explanation: This sentence reveals the central irony of the story from the beginning. It explicitly states that the astrologer has no genuine knowledge of astrology. His profession is a complete facade. The comparisonтАФthat he is as much a stranger to the stars as his innocent customers areтАФhighlights the fraudulent nature of his business. His success is not due to any astrological skill, but to his shrewdness, long practice, and sharp understanding of human psychology. This line immediately establishes the protagonist as an imposter.

written.q: 1. (a) What method/approach is suggested by NCTB? Marks: 4
written.a:
Method Suggested by NCTB

NCTB suggests the Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) approach for teaching English. Its main goal is to help students use English in real-life situations by focusing on communication and interaction, rather than just memorizing grammar rules.

written.q: (b) What are the advantages and disadvantages of this suggested method/approach? Marks: 4
written.a:
Advantages and Disadvantages of CLT

Advantages:

  • Student-Focused: Makes students active learners through activities like role-plays and group discussions.
  • Develops Fluency: Helps students speak more fluently and confidently by focusing on communication.
  • Motivating: Makes learning interesting by using real-life topics and interactive activities.
  • Develops All Skills: Helps develop all four language skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing) in an integrated way.

Disadvantages:

  • Difficult in Large Classes: It is hard to use effectively in the large, crowded classrooms of Bangladesh.
  • Lack of Teacher Training: Many teachers are not well-trained to use the CLT method properly.
  • Less Focus on Accuracy: The focus on fluency can sometimes lead to students making more grammar mistakes.
  • Mismatch with Exams: The current exam system often tests grammar rules, which conflicts with the goals of CLT.

written.q: Or, (a) What is the difference between GT method and CLT method?
written.a:
Difference between GTM and CLT

The Grammar-Translation Method (GTM) and Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) are very different. GTM's main goal is to help students read texts and learn grammar rules through translation. It is teacher-centered and students are passive. In contrast, CLT's main goal is to help students communicate effectively in real life. It is student-centered, promoting active interaction in English.

written.q: (b) Why is transition from GT to CLT important for teaching English at the secondary level in Bangladesh?
written.a:
Importance of Transition from GTM to CLT

Changing from GTM to CLT is important for teaching English in Bangladesh for these reasons:

  • Global Needs: Students need to speak and understand English for today's world of global communication, technology, and business, which CLT addresses.
  • Practical Skills: CLT teaches practical communication skills needed for jobs and higher education. GTM students often know rules but cannot speak English.
  • Motivation: CLT's interactive activities are more interesting and motivating for students than GTM's focus on memorizing rules.
  • Complete Language Learning: CLT develops all four language skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing), while GTM focuses only on reading and writing.

written.q: 2. (a) What is EFL? What are the benefits of learning English? Marks: 1+3=4
written.a:
EFL and Benefits of Learning English

EFL (English as a Foreign Language)

EFL means learning English in a country where it is not the main language, such as Bangladesh. In an EFL context, students learn English in school but have limited chances to use it in their daily lives.

Benefits of Learning English

  • Access to Knowledge: English gives access to a vast world of information on the internet and in science and business.
  • Higher Education: It is essential for studying in most universities abroad and for accessing academic books.
  • Better Career Prospects: Knowing English opens up better job opportunities in national and international companies.
  • Cross-Cultural Communication: It allows people to communicate with others from different countries and cultures.

written.q: (b) Write a critical appreciation of the poem, "Stopping by woods on a snowy evening." Marks: 4
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening"

Robert Frost's 'Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening' is a poem that seems simple but has a deep meaning. It describes a traveler stopping to watch the snow, but its real theme is the conflict between enjoying nature's beauty and fulfilling life's duties.

The poem uses simple language and a steady rhythm to create a quiet, thoughtful mood. The woods are 'lovely, dark and deep,' symbolizing the pull of beauty, peace, and perhaps even death. But the speaker remembers his 'promises to keep,' which represent his responsibilities in life.

The final repeated line, 'And miles to go before I sleep,' has two meanings. Literally, he has a long journey. Figuratively, 'miles to go' refers to the duties of his life, and 'sleep' can mean death. It is a timeless reflection on human responsibility.

written.q: Or, (a) What are the challenges of the traditional teaching system of English in Bangladesh?
written.a:
Challenges of Traditional English Teaching

The traditional English teaching system in Bangladesh, based on the Grammar-Translation Method (GTM), has several major problems:

  • Lack of Communication Skills: It focuses on memorizing grammar, so students pass exams but cannot speak or use English in real life.
  • Passive Learning: The classroom is teacher-dominated, where students just listen. This makes learning passive and boring.
  • Exam-Oriented: Teaching is focused on passing exams that test grammar rules, not on practical language use.
  • Core Skills are Ignored: The most important skills for communication, speaking and listening, are almost completely neglected.

written.q: (b) How does Shelley contrast the life of the bird and man in the poem "To a Skylark"?
written.a:
Contrast Between Bird and Man in "To a Skylark"

In "To a Skylark," Shelley creates a powerful contrast between the pure joy of the skylark and the sad existence of humans.

  • The Skylark's Joy: The bird is a symbol of pure, natural happiness. Its song is an effortless expression of joy because it knows no pain, sadness, or fear of the future. It lives entirely in the present moment.
  • Human Sadness: In contrast, human life is full of suffering. Shelley writes, "We look before and after, / And pine for what is not." This means humans are burdened by worrying about the past and future, and even our happiest moments contain some pain.

The skylark represents an ideal state of joy that humans long for but cannot achieve due to our complex thoughts and emotions.

written.q: 3. What are Francis Bacon's views on studies in his essay "Of Studies"? Illustrate. Marks: 8
written.a:
Bacon's Views in "Of Studies"

In his essay "Of Studies," Francis Bacon gives practical advice on why and how we should study. He argues that studying is essential for a well-rounded and effective life.

His main views are:

  1. Three Purposes of Study: Bacon states the three main benefits of study are "for delight" (personal enjoyment), "for ornament" (to improve conversation), and "for ability" (to improve judgment in business and life).
  2. How to Read: He famously compares reading to eating: "Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested." This means we should read books according to their value.
  3. Study and Experience: Bacon emphasizes that book knowledge alone is not enough. It must be balanced with practical, real-world experience to be truly useful.
  4. Study as a Cure: He suggests that different subjects can cure different mental weaknesses, just as physical exercise cures bodily defects. For example, mathematics can help a wandering mind to focus.

In short, Bacon views study as a vital tool for development, but it must be practiced with purpose and balanced with experience.

written.q: 4. Write a critical appreciation of the poem "She Dwelt Among the Untrodden ways". Marks: 8
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways"

William Wordsworth's "She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways" is a short, simple, but deeply emotional poem. It captures the Romantic themes of unnoticed beauty and the personal pain of loss.

The poem tells of a girl named Lucy who lived in an isolated place, so her beauty and virtue went unpraised. Wordsworth uses two metaphors from nature to describe her. He compares her to a "violet by a mossy stone," suggesting a hidden, humble beauty. He also compares her to a single "star," highlighting how special and unique she was to him.

The final stanza brings a sudden sadness. Lucy's death, like her life, was unnoticed by the world. But the last two lines reveal the poet's intense personal grief: "But she is in her grave, and, oh, / The difference to me!" This cry of personal pain transforms the poem into a powerful and universal expression of love and loss.

written.q: 5. Explain with reference to the context: (a) The woods are lovely, dark and deep, But I have promises to keep, And miles to go before I sleep. And miles to go before I sleep.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: These are the famous closing lines of Robert Frost's poem, "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening."

Context: The speaker has paused his journey to watch snow falling in a dark, silent wood, feeling captivated by the peaceful scene.

Explanation: These lines show the poem's central conflict: the pull of nature's beauty versus the demands of duty. The "lovely, dark and deep" woods represent the attraction of peace and perhaps even death. However, the speaker cannot stay because he has "promises to keep"тАФhis responsibilities in life. The repeated line "And miles to go before I sleep" literally means he has a long journey. Figuratively, it suggests he has many duties to fulfill before his final rest, or death.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (b) Beauty is truth, truth is beauty that is all Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: These are the famous final lines from John Keats's poem, "Ode on a Grecian Urn."

Context: The poet is looking at timeless scenes depicted on an ancient Greek urn and thinking about the contrast between the eternal beauty of art and the short, imperfect nature of human life.

Explanation: This statement is the poem's central message. "Beauty is truth, truth beauty" suggests that true, lasting beauty, like that found in art, is a form of permanent truth. In a world of change and suffering, this offers comfort. The urn seems to say that understanding this connection is the most important wisdom we can gain in life. It provides meaning by connecting us to something timeless.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (c) The difference in Affection of parents towards their several children is many times unequal, And sometimes unworthy.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: This line is from Francis Bacon's insightful essay, "Of Parents and Children."

Context: In this essay, Bacon discusses common tendencies and mistakes parents make and offers practical advice on raising children.

Explanation: Here, Bacon is making a sharp observation about parental favoritism. He states that parents often show unequal affection to their different children, and he considers this to be wrong or "unworthy." He notes that this partiality can create jealousy and rivalry among siblings, harming family harmony. The line serves as a warning for parents to be conscious and fair in showing affection to all their children.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (d) He was as much a stranger to the stars as were his innocent customers.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: This line is from the beginning of R.K. Narayan's short story, "An Astrologer's Day."

Context: The narrator is introducing the astrologer and describing how he sets up his business with various tools to look impressive and mystical to his clients.

Explanation: This sentence reveals the story's main secret from the start. It means the astrologer knew nothing about astrology, just like his customers. The comparison highlights that his entire business is a lie. His success comes not from any real knowledge but from his cleverness, practice, and his sharp understanding of people's problems. The line immediately establishes the protagonist as a charlatan, or a clever fake.

written.q: 1. (a) What are the advantages and disadvantages of the Grammar-Translation Method? Describe. Marks: 4
written.a:
Advantages and Disadvantages of GTM

Advantages:

  • Easy to Use: The method is easy for teachers to apply, even in large classes, as it relies on the textbook. The teacher does not need to be a fluent speaker of the target language.
  • Good for Reading and Writing: It helps students develop strong reading skills for literature and improves their writing accuracy through translation.
  • Focus on Accuracy: The strong focus on grammar rules helps students build a solid grammatical foundation in the language.

Disadvantages:

  • Ignores Communication: It almost completely neglects the important skills of listening and speaking, so students often cannot communicate in the language.
  • Unnatural Learning: It is an unnatural way to learn a language as it focuses on rules first, not on natural use and interaction.
  • Often Boring: The focus on memorizing rules and vocabulary, along with constant translation, often makes the learning process boring for students.

written.q: (b) Write a critical appreciation of the poem, "Ode on a Grecian Urn". Marks: 4
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "Ode on a Grecian Urn"

John Keats's "Ode on a Grecian Urn" is a beautiful poem about the relationship between art, beauty, and life. It contrasts the short, imperfect nature of human life with the eternal, perfect world of art depicted on the urn.

The poem addresses the urn as a timeless and pure object. The scenes on itтАФlovers, a musician, a religious ceremonyтАФare frozen in a moment of perfect beauty, free from the decay and sadness of real life. The poet says the "unheard melodies" are sweeter because they are eternal and exist in our imagination.

The poem's main philosophical idea is in its famous conclusion: "Beauty is truth, truth beauty." This suggests that the highest truth we can experience in our temporary world is through the eternal beauty preserved in art. The poem's rich imagery and deep questions make it a masterpiece of Romantic poetry.

written.q: Or, (a) What are the main features of CLT?
written.a:
Main Features of CLT

The main features of Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) are:

  • Focus on Communication: The main goal is to enable students to use the language to communicate effectively in real-life situations.
  • Meaning is Most Important: Communicating meaning is seen as more important than perfect grammar. Fluency is often prioritized over accuracy.
  • Use of Authentic Materials: CLT uses real-life materials like newspapers, menus, and ads to show students language as it is actually used.
  • Student-Centered Activities: Students learn through interactive activities like pair work, group work, and role-plays.
  • Integration of Skills: All four language skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing) are taught together.
  • Teacher as Facilitator: The teacher acts as a guide who creates opportunities for communication, rather than just being an authority.

written.q: (b) Describe Frost's treatment of Nature in the poem, "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening".
written.a:
Frost's Treatment of Nature

In "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening," Robert Frost shows nature in a complex way, presenting it with a dual quality.

  • A Source of Beauty and Peace: The speaker is captivated by the beauty of the snow-filled woods. The scene is quiet and peaceful, offering a temporary escape from the busy world. The imagery of the "frozen lake" and "downy flake" creates a serene atmosphere.
  • A Symbol of Temptation: At the same time, the woods are "dark and deep," which suggests a dangerous temptation. They represent the allure of abandoning one's duties, and perhaps even a longing for the final rest of death.

Ultimately, Frost's view is realistic. He shows that while humans need the peace and beauty of nature, they also have social responsibilities ("promises to keep") that they must fulfill. Nature is a refuge, but the journey of life must go on.

written.q: 2. (a) What is interlanguage theory? Mention different purposes of learning English. Marks: 4
written.a:
Interlanguage Theory and Purposes of Learning English

Interlanguage Theory

Interlanguage theory suggests that when a person learns a second language, they create their own unique language system. This system is not their first language, nor is it the target language; it is something in between. According to this theory, a learner's errors are not random mistakes but are seen as logical, systematic steps in the process of learning the new language's rules.

Purposes of Learning English

  • Global Communication: To communicate with people from different countries, as English is a global language.
  • Higher Education: To pursue studies in universities at home and abroad and to access academic resources.
  • Career Advancement: To get better job opportunities, as English proficiency is needed in many professions.
  • Access to Information: To get information from the internet and to enjoy global media, books, and movies.

written.q: (b) What is the theme of the poem, "Lucy Gray" by William Wordsworth? Marks: 4
written.a:
Theme of "Lucy Gray"

The main theme of William Wordsworth's "Lucy Gray" is the mysterious connection between childhood innocence and nature, along with the sadness of losing a child. The poem tells the story of Lucy Gray, a young girl who gets lost and dies in a snowstorm.

However, the poem suggests that Lucy does not completely disappear. Instead, she becomes a spirit of nature. She is a "living thing" who can still be seen singing her song "that whistles in the wind." While the poem deals with loss and grief, it offers the romantic idea that nature protects the pure spirit of a child, giving her a different kind of immortal life.

written.q: Or, (a) What is the difference between Method and Approach? Describe in detail.
written.a:
Difference between Method and Approach

In language teaching, 'Approach' and 'Method' are two related but different terms.

An Approach is a set of theories or beliefs about what language is and how it is learned. It's the big idea or philosophy behind the teaching. An approach answers the question 'Why?'. For example, the idea that language is primarily for communication is a communicative approach.

A Method is the practical, step-by-step plan for teaching based on a chosen approach. It outlines specific objectives, activities, and the roles of teachers and students. A method answers the question 'How?'. For example, Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) is a method that uses techniques like role-playing to put the communicative approach into action.

In short, an approach is the theory ('the why'), while a method is the practical plan for how to implement that theory ('the how').

written.q: (b) Why does the Astrologer advise the stranger to go home immediately?
written.a:
The Astrologer's Advice

In R.K. Narayan's "An Astrologer's Day," the astrologer advises the stranger, Guru Nayak, to go home immediately to save his own life. The astrologer recognizes Guru Nayak as the man he had tried to kill many years ago.

He is terrified that his secret past has been discovered. As a clever act of self-preservation, he tells Nayak that the man who attacked him is already dead. He then warns Nayak never to travel south again. This clever advice ends Nayak's hunt for revenge and ensures the astrologer's own identity and safety remain protected from a great danger from his past.

written.q: 3. What is the analysis of Francis Bacon's essay 'Of Parents and Children'? Marks: 8
written.a:
Analysis of Bacon's "Of Parents and Children"

Francis Bacon's essay "Of Parents and Children" is a practical and logical analysis of parenting, focusing on reason and balance rather than sentimentality.

The key points of his analysis are:

  • Balanced Affection: Bacon argues that a moderate approach to love is best. Too much indulgence spoils children, while too little affection crushes their spirits.
  • Financial Prudence: He advises parents to be generous with allowances but to keep control over the main finances to teach responsibility. Being too cheap can make children resentful.
  • Avoiding Favoritism: Bacon observes that showing more love to one child over others is wrong and leads to jealousy and conflict within the family.
  • Career Guidance: He states that parents have a duty to observe their child's natural talents and guide them to a suitable profession, rather than forcing them into one.

Overall, Bacon's essay analyzes parenting as a practical task that requires reason, balance, and a keen understanding of human nature.

written.q: 4. What is a learning outcome? Identify the objectives of the English Curriculum. Marks: 8
written.a:
Learning Outcomes and Curriculum Objectives

Learning Outcome

A learning outcome is a clear and specific statement that says what a student should know, understand, or be able to do after a learning experience (like a lesson or a course). It focuses on the end result or the evidence of learning, not the teaching process. For example: "By the end of the lesson, students will be able to write a five-sentence paragraph using the past tense."

Objectives of the English Curriculum

The main goal of the English Curriculum in Bangladesh is to develop students' communicative competenceтАФthe ability to use English effectively in real life. The specific objectives are based on the four language skills:

  • Listening: To understand spoken English in different situations like conversations and announcements.
  • Speaking: To express ideas and feelings in English with reasonable fluency in everyday situations.
  • Reading: To read and understand different kinds of texts (like stories and articles) to get information and for pleasure.
  • Writing: To write clearly and correctly in English for various practical purposes.

written.q: 5. Explain with reference to the context: (a) My little horse must think it queer To stop without a farmhouse near Between the woods and frozen lake The darkest evening of the year.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: These lines are from the second stanza of Robert Frost's famous poem, "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening."

Context: The speaker has stopped his sleigh journey to watch snow fall in a lonely, quiet wood on the darkest evening of the year.

Explanation: In these lines, the speaker imagines his horse's thoughts. The horse, a practical animal, finds it strange ('queer') to stop without a clear reason like a farmhouse. The speaker's decision to pause just to enjoy the beauty of the woods is a uniquely human act. This shows a contrast between the horse's practical, instinct-driven world and the human's ability to appreciate beauty and peace. It highlights the poem's theme of the pull between worldly duties and the quiet allure of nature.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (b) "I charge only three pice per question, and what you get ought to be good enough for your money."
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: This line is spoken by the protagonist, the astrologer, in R.K. Narayan's short story, "An Astrologer's Day."

Context: The astrologer is talking to a new, challenging client (who is later revealed to be Guru Nayak) and setting his price before he agrees to answer the man's questions.

Explanation: This statement shows the astrologer's clever, business-like personality. By stating his price firmly, he takes control of the situation. The phrase "what you get ought to be good enough for your money" is a smart trick. It works as both a promise of value and a way to manage the customer's expectations. It demonstrates his experience in handling people in his fraudulent but successful profession.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (c) Histories make men wise; Poets witty; the Mathematics subtle; natural philosophy deep; moral grave; logic and rhetoric able to contend.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: This famous line is from Francis Bacon's influential essay, "Of Studies."

Context: In this part of the essay, Bacon argues that different academic subjects shape a person's mind in specific ways, much like different exercises strengthen the body.

Explanation: This sentence lists different subjects and the specific mental skills they develop. Bacon suggests that:

  • Studying histories makes people wise by learning from the past.
  • Reading poetry makes people creative and clever with words ('witty').
  • Mathematics makes the mind sharp and focused ('subtle').
  • Natural philosophy (science) encourages deep and thorough thinking.
  • Moral philosophy makes a person serious and principled.
  • Logic and rhetoric make a person skilled in argument and debate.
This illustrates Bacon's belief in the practical power of a well-rounded education to improve one's character.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (d) We look before and after, And pine for what is not: Our sincerest laughter With some pain is fraught; Our sweetest songs are those that tell our saddest thought.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to Context

Reference: These lines are from Percy Bysshe Shelley's poem, "To a Skylark."

Context: The poet is listening to the purely happy song of a skylark and is contrasting the bird's simple joy with the complex and painful nature of human life.

Explanation: These lines explain why humans can never be completely happy. Shelley says humans are always burdened by looking at the past ("before") or worrying about the future ("after"). We constantly desire things we don't have. Because of this, even our most genuine laughter has some pain mixed in with it. He concludes that our most beautiful art, our "sweetest songs," often come from our deepest sadness. This is the key difference between the bird's natural, effortless happiness and the complex, self-aware emotions of humans.

written.q: 1. (a) Discuss Keats as a poet of nature in the light of 'Ode on a Grecian Urn'.
written.a:
Keats, Nature, and the Grecian Urn

In "Ode on a Grecian Urn," Keats shows a complex relationship with nature. He is less interested in living, wild nature and more interested in how nature is preserved forever through art.

The urn shows natural scenes, like trees and a piper playing music. However, Keats focuses on their permanence in the artwork. The trees on the urn will never lose their leaves, and the piper's song is eternal. This is different from real nature, which always changes with the seasons.

So, Keats uses these images of nature to show that art is powerful because it can freeze a beautiful moment and make it last forever. For him, the beauty of art is superior because it is unchanging, unlike the temporary beauty of the real natural world. The poem celebrates art's victory over time and nature.

written.q: (b) Describe 'G-T Method' and 'CLT'. How do they differ?
written.a:
GTM vs. CLT: Description and Differences

Grammar-Translation Method (GTM)

This is a traditional method where the main goal is to learn a language to read its literature. Classes focus on learning grammar rules and vocabulary lists, and the main activity is translating texts.

Communicative Language Teaching (CLT)

This is a modern approach where the main goal is to help students communicate in real-life situations. The focus is on meaningful interaction, with activities like role-plays, group work, and problem-solving tasks.

Key Differences

  • Goal: GTM is for reading texts; CLT is for real-life communication.
  • Focus: GTM focuses on grammar rules; CLT focuses on communicating meaning.
  • Skills: GTM emphasizes reading and writing; CLT teaches all four skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing).
  • Classroom: GTM is teacher-centered and uses translation; CLT is student-centered and uses interactive tasks.

written.q: Or, (a) Which method is recommended in Bangladesh Secondary Curriculum? Advantages and disadvantages?
written.a:
Recommended Method in Bangladesh

The method recommended in the Bangladesh Secondary Curriculum is Communicative Language Teaching (CLT).

Advantages

  • It prepares students for real-life communication in English.
  • It makes learning more interesting and motivating with interactive activities.
  • It helps develop students' fluency and confidence in speaking.

Disadvantages

  • It is difficult to use in large, overcrowded classrooms.
  • Many teachers may not have the proper training to use CLT effectively.
  • The exam system often tests grammar, which conflicts with CLT's communicative goals.

written.q: (b) Illustrate Bacon's ideas from 'Of Studies'.
written.a:
Bacon's Ideas in "Of Studies"

Francis Bacon's essay "Of Studies" gives practical advice on the purpose and practice of studying. His key ideas are:

  • Three Uses of Study: Bacon states that studies are for "delight" (personal joy), "ornament" (to improve conversation), and "ability" (to make better judgments).
  • Different Ways of Reading: He advises that "Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested." This means a reader should be selective and read a book according to its importance.
  • Balancing Study with Experience: Bacon argues that knowledge from books must be balanced with practical, real-life experience to be truly useful.
  • Study as a Cure for the Mind: He suggests that different subjects can fix different mental weaknesses, just as exercise fixes the body. For example, mathematics can help a wandering mind focus.

written.q: 2. (a) Discuss the theme of 'An Astrologer's Day'.
written.a:
Themes in "An Astrologer's Day"

The main themes of R.K. Narayan's "An Astrologer's Day" are **guilt, fate, and appearance versus reality**. The story shows how the protagonist's entire life is shaped by guilt from a past crime. The theme of appearance vs. reality is clear: he looks like a wise astrologer but knows nothing about stars. The story's climax, where he meets the man he thought he had killed, raises questions about fate and coincidence. A key theme is the great relief he feels when he is finally freed from the heavy burden of guilt he carried for years.

written.q: (b) Critical appreciation of 'Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening'.
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening"

Robert Frost's "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening" is a poem that seems simple but has a deep meaning. On the surface, it is about a traveler admiring a snow-filled wood. But it is really about the conflict between enjoying nature's beauty and the call of duty.

The poem's simple language, regular rhyme scheme, and steady rhythm create a quiet, peaceful mood. The central tension is in the last stanza. The woods are "lovely, dark and deep," representing the attraction of beauty and rest. But the speaker has "promises to keep," which are his duties in life. The repeated last line, "And miles to go before I sleep," highlights his many responsibilities before his final rest. It's a timeless poem about the human journey.

written.q: Or, (a) Characteristics and function of interlanguage.
written.a:
Interlanguage: Characteristics and Function

Characteristics

  • Systematic: It has its own consistent rules, even if they are 'wrong' in the target language.
  • Dynamic: It is always changing as the learner gets more knowledge.
  • Variable: A learner's performance can change depending on the situation.

Function

Its main function is to act as a bridge. It is a temporary language system that helps a learner move from their first language (L1) toward the target language (L2). It allows learners to communicate even with limited knowledge and helps them learn more.

written.q: (b) Discuss Wordsworth's pantheism in 'Lucy Poems'.
written.a:
Wordsworth's Pantheism in the "Lucy Poems"

Pantheism is the belief that God or the divine is in everything in nature. In his "Lucy Poems," Wordsworth shows this belief by creating a deep, spiritual connection between his character, Lucy, and the natural world.

Lucy is portrayed as a "child of nature." Her beauty is described with natural images, like a "violet by a mossy stone" and a star. This suggests she is a part of nature. In "Three Years She Grew," Nature itself adopts Lucy as its child.

After she dies, Lucy does not just disappear. Instead, she becomes part of nature again, one with "rocks, and stones, and trees." This idea that her spirit lives on as a part of the natural world is a clear example of Wordsworth's pantheistic beliefs.

written.q: 3. Critical appreciation of 'To a Skylark'.
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "To a Skylark"

Percy Bysshe Shelley's "To a Skylark" is a famous Romantic poem. It celebrates the pure, happy song of a skylark and contrasts it with the sadness and complexity of human life.

The language is rich with brilliant similes and metaphors, as Shelley tries to describe the amazing song. He compares it to a poet's hymns, a maiden's song, and a rose's scent, using vivid imagery.

The central theme is the contrast between the ideal and the real. The skylark is a "blithe Spirit," a symbol of perfect happiness, free from human problems like pain and worry. In contrast, humans "look before and after, / And pine for what is not."

The poem ends with the poet wishing to learn the bird's secret joy to create inspiring art. This makes the poem a deep reflection on nature, inspiration, and human life.

written.q: 4. Problems of traditional English teaching in Bangladesh.
written.a:
Problems of Traditional English Teaching in Bangladesh

The traditional English teaching system in Bangladesh, mostly using the Grammar-Translation Method (GTM), has several major problems:

  1. Fails to Teach Communication: It focuses on grammar rules, so students learn the rules but cannot actually speak or use English in daily life.
  2. Passive Learning: The teacher does all the talking while students just listen. This makes classes boring and learning ineffective.
  3. Exam-Focused System: Teaching is driven by exams that test memorization of rules, not practical language skills.
  4. Demotivating for Students: The focus on abstract rules and memorizing is often tedious and uninspiring for students.
  5. Key Skills are Ignored: Speaking and listening, the most important communication skills, are almost completely neglected in the classroom.

written.q: 5. Explain with reference to the context: (a) Studies pass into the character.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This line is from Francis Bacon's essay, "Of Studies."

Context: Bacon is discussing how different subjects shape a person's mind and personality.

Explanation: This statement means that what we study becomes a part of our character and behavior. Studying doesn't just give us information; it shapes how we think and act. For example, studying logic can make a person more reasonable in daily life. In short, our studies help make us who we are.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (b) Stranger to stars.
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This phrase summarizes a line from R.K. Narayan's short story, "An Astrologer's Day." The full line is: "He was as much a stranger to the stars as were his innocent customers."

Context: The narrator is describing the main character, who works as an astrologer but has no real knowledge of the subject.

Explanation: The phrase "stranger to the stars" means the astrologer knew nothing about astrology. It highlights the main irony of the story: the man who claims to read the stars is completely ignorant about them. His success comes from being clever and understanding people, not from mystical knowledge. This phrase establishes him as a fake from the very beginning.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (c) The woods are lovely...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is part of a famous line from Robert Frost's poem, "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening." The full line is, "The woods are lovely, dark and deep."

Context: The speaker has stopped his journey to watch the snow fall in a quiet wood and is mesmerized by the beautiful scene.

Explanation: This phrase shows the powerful attraction the speaker feels for nature. The woods are "lovely," representing beauty, but also "dark and deep," which suggests something mysterious and tempting. This could be the desire to escape from life's duties, or even the final peace of death. The phrase sets up the poem's central conflict: the temptation of nature versus the responsibility to continue the journey of life.

written.q: Explain with reference to the context: (d) Teach me half the gladness...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is the start of a line from the final stanza of Shelley's poem, "To a Skylark." The full line is: "Teach me half the gladness / That thy brain must know."

Context: The poet has been listening to the joyous song of a skylark and contrasting the bird's pure happiness with human sadness.

Explanation: This is a direct request from the poet to the skylark, asking the bird to teach him the secret of its pure joy ("gladness"). The poet believes that if he could learn even half of the bird's happiness, he could write poetry so beautiful that the whole world would listen. This line expresses the Romantic ideal of nature being a source of divine inspiration for creating perfect art.

written.q: 1. Main features of the current National Curriculum for English (secondary level).
written.a:
Main Features of the National English Curriculum

The current English curriculum for secondary schools in Bangladesh is based on several key features to make learning effective:

  • Communicative Competence: The main goal is to help students use English in real life, not just know grammar rules.
  • Integration of Four Skills: It focuses on developing all four language skillsтАФlistening, speaking, reading, and writingтАФtogether.
  • Student-Centered Learning: It encourages students to be active through pair work and group work, instead of just listening to the teacher.
  • Use of Authentic Materials: It uses real-life materials like newspaper articles or menus to make learning more practical.
  • Task-Based Learning: Students learn by completing communicative tasks, which means they use language for a clear purpose.

written.q: 2. English teaching methods. Which one is appropriate in Bangladesh and why?
written.a:
English Teaching Methods and the Bangladeshi Context

Common English teaching methods include the Grammar-Translation Method (GTM), the Direct Method, and Communicative Language Teaching (CLT).

For Bangladesh, Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) is the most appropriate and officially recommended method.

Why CLT is Appropriate:

  • Global Needs: It focuses on speaking and listening, which are essential for global communication today.
  • Future Skills: It gives students practical language skills needed for higher education and good jobs.
  • Motivation: Using interactive activities makes learning more interesting for students than just memorizing rules.
  • All-Round Development: It develops all four language skills together for a more complete ability in English.

written.q: 3. How does Shelley contrast bird vs man in 'To a Skylark'?
written.a:
Contrast Between the Bird and Man in "To a Skylark"

In "To a Skylark," Shelley shows a sharp contrast between the pure joy of the skylark and the sad, complicated life of humans.

  • The Skylark's Joy: The bird is a symbol of perfect, natural happiness. Its song is full of joy because it lives only in the present and doesn't know human problems like sadness, nostalgia, or fear.
  • Human Suffering: In contrast, humans are always worried. Shelley writes, "We look before and after, / And pine for what is not." This means we are burdened by past memories and future anxieties, so even our happiest moments have some pain.

The skylark represents an ideal, joyful state that humans wish for but cannot achieve. This highlights the Romantic idea that nature has a spiritual purity that people have lost.

written.q: 4. 'Nature and human life are interrelated' тАФ Illustrate from Wordsworth's poems.
written.a:
Interrelation of Nature and Human Life in Wordsworth

For William Wordsworth, nature and human life are deeply connected. He saw nature as a living force that is a teacher, guide, and source of spiritual comfort for people.

  • Nature as a Teacher: In poems like "The Tables Turned," Wordsworth says that nature can teach us more about right and wrong than wise men can.
  • Nature as a Comforter: In "Tintern Abbey," he remembers how the beauty of nature gave him comfort and peace during stressful times in the city.
  • Nature and Innocence: In his "Lucy Poems," Lucy is a "child of nature." After her death, she becomes a part of nature again, one with "rocks, and stones, and trees," showing their deep, unbreakable bond.

For Wordsworth, living in harmony with nature leads to a life of joy, wisdom, and spiritual peace.

written.q: 5. Significance of title 'An Astrologer's Day'.
written.a:
Significance of the Title "An Astrologer's Day"

The title of R.K. Narayan's story, "An Astrologer's Day," is significant and ironic. It sounds like a normal day, but the events of this one day are extraordinary for the astrologer.

  • A Day of Confrontation: It is the day his hidden past returns when he meets Guru Nayak, the man he once tried to kill.
  • A Day of Revelation: On this day, he learns the truth that his victim actually survived.
  • A Day of Relief: Most importantly, he is finally freed from the heavy guilt he has carried for years. As he says, "a great load is gone" from him.

Thus, the title highlights the most life-changing day for the astrologer, where he finds peace from his past, not from the stars.

written.q: 6. Analysis of Bacon's essay 'Of Parents and Children'.
written.a:
Analysis of Bacon's "Of Parents and Children"

Francis Bacon's essay "Of Parents and Children" is a practical guide to parenting that focuses on reason and balance over emotion.

The key points of his analysis are:

  • Balanced Affection: Bacon argues that a moderate approach to love is best. Too much love spoils children, while too little makes them sad and resentful.
  • Wise with Money: Parents should be generous with allowances but also teach their children to be financially responsible.
  • Avoid Favoritism: He warns that loving one child more than others is wrong and causes jealousy and family conflict.
  • Career Guidance: Parents should observe their child's natural talents and guide them toward a suitable career, not force them into one.

Bacon analyzes parenting as a practical task that needs reason, foresight, and a good understanding of human nature.

written.q: 7. Reference explanation: (a) Joys of parents...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Francis Bacon's essay, "Of Parents and Children." The full line is, "The joys of parents are secret; and so are their griefs and fears."

Context: Bacon is writing about the inner emotional world of parents.

Explanation: This statement means that the greatest happiness and the deepest worries a parent feels about their children are often private and hidden from the outside world. It shows that parenthood brings both secret joys and secret burdens.

written.q: Reference explanation: (b) My little horse...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Robert Frost's poem, "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening." The lines are, "My little horse must think it queer / To stop without a farmhouse near."

Context: The speaker has stopped his sleigh in a deserted, snowy wood just to watch the beautiful scene.

Explanation: The speaker imagines his horse's practical point of view. The horse finds the stop strange ("queer") because there is no practical reason for it, like a farmhouse. This highlights the difference between the animal's world of instinct and the human's ability to appreciate beauty for its own sake.

written.q: Reference explanation: (c) Beauty is truth...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from the end of John Keats's poem, "Ode on a Grecian Urn." The line is, "'Beauty is truth, truth beauty,'тАФthat is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know."

Context: The speaker is concluding his thoughts on the timeless scenes of beauty shown on the ancient urn.

Explanation: This famous line suggests that the highest form of truth we can understand is found in eternal beauty, especially beauty preserved by art. In a world of change and death, the permanent beauty of the urn provides a kind of truth that gives comfort and meaning to humanity.

written.q: Reference explanation: (d) Some books are to be tasted...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Francis Bacon's essay, "Of Studies." The full line is, "Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested."

Context: Bacon is giving advice on how to read different kinds of books with purpose.

Explanation: Bacon uses eating as a metaphor for reading. He means we should use different reading strategies for different books. Some only need a quick look ("tasted"), some can be read quickly for the main ideas ("swallowed"), and only a few important books should be read slowly and carefully to be fully understood ("chewed and digested").
