written.q: 1. (a) What is a technique? How do pair work, group work, role play and drama help?
written.a:
Techniques in Language Teaching

What is a Technique?

In language teaching, a technique is a specific classroom activity or task used to help students learn, like a game or an exercise. It is the practical 'how-to' part of a lesson, based on a chosen method.

How Different Techniques Help:

  • Pair Work and Group Work: These techniques give students more time to talk in a supportive environment. They feel more comfortable practicing the language with friends and also learn to work together.
  • Role Play and Drama: These techniques allow students to use language in pretend real-life situations. This helps them practice communication in a meaningful way, improves their speaking confidence, and makes learning fun and memorable.

written.q: 2. Which method is suggested by NCTB and why? Characteristics?
written.a:
Method Suggested by NCTB

The method suggested by the NCTB for teaching English in Bangladesh is Communicative Language Teaching (CLT).

Why CLT is Suggested:

CLT's main goal is to help students communicate effectively in English, a skill needed for higher education, jobs, and global communication. It focuses on practical language use, not just memorizing grammar rules.

Characteristics of CLT:

  • The main goal is achieving real-life communication skills.
  • It focuses on meaning, not just on perfect grammar.
  • It is student-centered and uses interactive activities like pair work and group work.
  • It teaches all four skills together: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

written.q: 3. Essay on pictorial quality of Keats.
written.a:
The Pictorial Quality in Keats's Poetry

John Keats is often called a "poet-painter" because his poems create strong, clear pictures in the reader's mind. He masterfully uses language that appeals to all five senses, making his poetry a rich and immersive experience.

Keats's great strength is his use of **sensory imagery**. He shows beauty through detailed descriptions. In "Ode to Autumn," for example, he paints vivid pictures of the season, like "mellow fruitfulness" and ripe apples, and personifies Autumn as a sleepy farm worker. We can almost see and feel the scene.

Similarly, in "The Eve of St. Agnes," his descriptive power is at its peak. He describes colourful light from a stained-glass window and a feast of delicious fruits and sweets, appealing to our senses of sight, taste, and smell.

This ability to create clear, sensory images makes Keats's poetry feel real and alive. He invites readers to see, hear, and feel his poems, which is why they remain so powerful.

written.q: 4. BaconтАЩs views on studies in 'Of Studies'.
written.a:
Bacon's Views in "Of Studies"

In his essay "Of Studies," Francis Bacon gives practical advice on the purpose and practice of studying for a well-rounded life.

His main views are:

  1. The Three Purposes of Study: Bacon says we study "for delight" (personal enjoyment), "for ornament" (to improve conversation), and "for ability" (to make better judgments in life and business).
  2. The Right Way to Read: He uses a metaphor of eating: "Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested." This means we should read books according to their importance.
  3. Study and Experience: He emphasizes that book knowledge is not enough; it must be combined with practical experience to be truly useful. Natural abilities are like plants that need 'pruning by study.'
  4. The Curative Power of Study: Bacon suggests that different subjects can fix different weaknesses of the mind, just like exercise fixes the body. For example, he says mathematics can help a wandering mind to focus.

written.q: 5. Character sketch of the astrologer.
written.a:
Character Sketch of the Astrologer

The astrologer in R.K. Narayan's story is a complex man whose fake identity is a result of a dark past. He is not a real astrologer but is very clever and perceptive at understanding people.

  • Clever and Perceptive: His success comes from observing people, not from knowing about stars. He uses smart guesses and vague statements to seem wise and mysterious.
  • Practical and Hardworking: He chose this fake profession to support his family and works long hours every day.
  • A Man with a Dark Past: The story reveals he is a fugitive. In his youth, he stabbed a man named Guru Nayak and fled his village, believing the man was dead.
  • Burdened by Guilt: He secretly carries the heavy guilt of thinking he is a murderer. He feels huge relief when he finds out Guru Nayak is alive, saying, "a great load is gone from me today."

written.q: 6. Critical appreciation of 'To a Skylark'.
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "To a Skylark"

Percy Bysshe Shelley's "To a Skylark" is a famous Romantic poem that celebrates the pure, happy song of a skylark and contrasts it with the sadness of human life.

The language is rich with brilliant similes and metaphors as Shelley tries to describe the amazing song, comparing it to a poet's hymns or a rose's scent.

The central theme is the contrast between the ideal (the bird's joy) and the real (human suffering). The skylark is a "blithe Spirit," a symbol of perfect happiness, free from human problems like pain and worry. In contrast, humans "look before and after, / And pine for what is not."

The poem ends with the poet's wish to learn the bird's secret joy to create inspiring art. This makes the poem a deep reflection on nature, inspiration, and human life.

written.q: 7. Reference explanation: (a) The woods are lovely...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Robert Frost's poem, "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening." The full line is, "The woods are lovely, dark and deep."

Context: The speaker has stopped his journey to watch the snow fall in a quiet wood and is mesmerized by the beautiful scene.

Explanation: This phrase shows the powerful attraction of nature. The woods are "lovely," representing beauty, but also "dark and deep," suggesting something mysterious and tempting. This could be the desire to escape from life's duties or even the final peace of death. The phrase sets up the poem's main conflict: the pull of nature's beauty versus the need to fulfill one's responsibilities.

written.q: Reference explanation: (b) Heard melodies...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from John Keats's poem, "Ode on a Grecian Urn." The full lines are, "Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard / Are sweeter..."

Context: The speaker is looking at a scene on the urn showing a piper playing music.

Explanation: This line shows the key idea that imagination is superior to reality. The speaker says real music ("heard melodies") is sweet, but the imagined music from the piper on the urn ("those unheard") is sweeter because it is perfect and eternal. It highlights the Romantic belief in the power of the imagination.

written.q: Reference explanation: (c) We look before...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Percy Bysshe Shelley's poem, "To a Skylark." The full lines are, "We look before and after, / And pine for what is not..."

Context: The poet is contrasting the pure joy of the skylark with the complicated nature of human life.

Explanation: This line captures the essence of human dissatisfaction. Shelley says humans can't be purely happy because we are always thinking about the past ("before") or worrying about the future ("after"). We constantly want things we don't have. Unlike the skylark, which lives joyfully in the present, humans are burdened by memory and anxiety, which prevents true joy.

written.q: Reference explanation: (d) Lucy Gray...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This refers to the main character from William Wordsworth's poem, "Lucy Gray; or, Solitude."

Context: The poem tells the story of a young girl who gets lost and vanishes during a snowstorm.

Explanation: Lucy Gray symbolizes the deep connection between childhood innocence and nature. After she disappears, the poem suggests she did not die but became a spirit of nature, singing a song "that whistles in the wind." This reflects the Romantic idea that an innocent spirit is absorbed into the natural world and lives on as a part of it. Lucy represents the purity and mystery that Wordsworth saw in both nature and childhood.

written.q: 1. KeatsтАЩ sense of beauty in 'Ode on a Grecian Urn'
written.a:
Keats's Sense of Beauty in "Ode on a Grecian Urn"

In "Ode on a Grecian Urn," John Keats presents a special idea of beauty. For him, the highest form of beauty is permanent and unchanging, as found in art. He contrasts this with the short and imperfect nature of human life.

Keats looks at the scenes on the urnтАФthe young lovers, the musicianтАФand sees a world of perfect, frozen beauty. Unlike in real life, the lovers will never grow old, and the musician's song is eternal. Their beautiful moment will never be lost to time.

This leads Keats to his famous conclusion, "Beauty is truth, truth beauty." His sense of beauty is a philosophical idea. He believes the eternal beauty of art provides a higher, more lasting truth than our changing reality. Through this timeless beauty, people can find meaning and comfort.

written.q: Or, theme of 'An Astrologer's Day'.
written.a:
Themes in "An Astrologer's Day"

The main themes of R.K. Narayan's "An Astrologer's Day" are **guilt, fate, and appearance versus reality**. The story shows how the protagonist's entire life is shaped by guilt from a crime he thinks he committed. The theme of appearance vs. reality is clear: he looks like a wise astrologer but actually knows nothing about stars. The story's climax, where he meets his past in the form of Guru Nayak, raises questions about fate. A key theme is the great relief that comes from absolution, as the astrologer is finally freed from the heavy burden of guilt he has carried for years.

written.q: 2. Critical appreciation of 'She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways'.
written.a:
Critical Appreciation of "She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways"

William Wordsworth's "She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways" is a short, simple, and very emotional poem. It captures the themes of unnoticed beauty and the personal pain of loss.

The poem's power comes from its simplicity. It tells of a girl named Lucy who lived in a lonely place, so she was unknown and unpraised: "A Maid whom there were none to praise / And very few to love."

Wordsworth uses two metaphors from nature to describe her unique beauty. He compares her to a hidden "violet by a mossy stone" and a single, bright "star," showing her shy beauty and how special she was to him.

The last stanza is suddenly very sad. He says her death went unnoticed by the world, but for him, the loss was huge, as expressed in the final cry of pain: "But she is in her grave, and, oh, / The difference to me!" This makes the poem a powerful expression of love and loss.

written.q: 3. GTM and CLT: Differences.
written.a:
Differences: GTM vs. CLT

The Grammar-Translation Method (GTM) and Communicative Language Teaching (CLT) are two very different ways of teaching English. Here are their key differences:

Feature Grammar-Translation Method (GTM) Communicative Language Teaching (CLT)
Goal To read literature and learn grammar rules. To communicate effectively in real life.
Focus Grammatical accuracy. Fluency and communicating meaning.
Skills Focuses on reading and writing. Teaches all four skills together.
Classroom Role Teacher-centered; students are passive. Student-centered; students are active.

written.q: 4. Main features of National Curriculum for English.
written.a:
Main Features of the National English Curriculum

The current National Curriculum for English in Bangladesh has several key features:

  • Communicative Competence: The main goal is to help students use English in real-life communication, not just to know grammar rules.
  • Integration of Four Skills: It focuses on developing all four language skillsтАФlistening, speaking, reading, and writingтАФtogether.
  • Student-Centered Learning: It encourages students to be active learners through pair work, group work, and role-plays.
  • Use of Authentic Materials: It uses real-life materials like newspaper articles or menus to make learning practical and meaningful.
  • Task-Based Learning: Students learn by completing communicative tasks, using the language for a clear purpose.

written.q: 5. Reference explanation: (a) Three years she grew...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is the first line of William Wordsworth's poem, "Three Years She Grew in Sun and Shower," one of his "Lucy poems."

Context: The poem begins after Lucy's birth, where Nature, personified as a loving being, declares it will raise Lucy as its own child.

Explanation: This line introduces the poem's main idea that Lucy will be a "child of nature." Nature plans to shape her character with its own qualities, from the calmness of clouds to the energy of storms. The poem shows Wordsworth's belief that nature is the best teacher and that living in harmony with it leads to a perfect life.

written.q: Reference explanation: (b) Crafty men contemn studies...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Francis Bacon's essay, "Of Studies." The full line is, "Crafty men contemn studies, simple men admire them, and wise men use them."

Context: Bacon is describing how different kinds of people view the value of studying and reading.

Explanation: Bacon classifies people into three types based on their attitude towards studies. "Crafty men" (cunning people who only trust experience) look down on studies as useless. "Simple men" (naive people) admire studies but don't understand how to apply them. However, "wise men" know how to use the knowledge from books in their practical lives. Bacon's point is that the true value of study is in its practical application.

written.q: Reference explanation: (c) Happy, happy boughs...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from John Keats's poem, "Ode on a Grecian Urn." The line is, "Ah, happy, happy boughs! that cannot shed / Your leaves, nor ever bid the Spring adieu..."

Context: The speaker is looking at a scene painted on the ancient urn that shows trees with green leaves.

Explanation: Keats calls the tree branches ("boughs") on the urn "happy" because they are frozen in time in a state of eternal spring. Unlike real trees that lose their leaves, the branches on the urn will never be bare. This highlights the poem's main theme: the contrast between the perfect, unchanging world of art and the temporary, changing world of reality. The boughs are happy because they are permanent.

written.q: Reference explanation: (d) We look before...
written.a:
Explanation with Reference to the Context

Reference: This is from Percy Bysshe Shelley's poem, "To a Skylark." The lines are, "We look before and after, / And pine for what is not..."

Context: The poet is contrasting the pure joy of the skylark with the complicated nature of human life.

Explanation: This line captures the essence of human dissatisfaction. Shelley states that humans cannot be truly happy because they are always thinking about the past ("look before") or worrying about the future ("after"). They constantly long for things they don't have. Unlike the skylark, which lives joyfully in the present moment, humans are burdened by memory and anxiety, which prevents pure joy.

english.title: An Astrologer's Day
english.content:
An Astrologer's Day

by R K Narayan

PUNCTUALLY at midday he opened his bag and spread out his professional equipment, which consisted of a dozen cowrie shells, a square piece of cloth with obscure mystic charts on it, a notebook, and a bundle of palmyra writing. His forehead was resplendent with sacred ash and vermilion, and his eyes sparkled with a sharp abnormal gleam which was really an outcome of a continual searching look for customers, but which his simple clients took to be a prophetic light and felt comforted. The power of his eyes was considerably enhanced by their position placed as they were between the painted forehead and the dark whiskers which streamed down his cheeks Even a half-witтАЩs eyes would sparkle in such a setting. To crown the effect he wound a saffron-coloured turban around his head. This colour scheme never failed. People were attracted to him as bees are attracted to cosmos or dahlia stalks. He sat under the boughs of a spreading tamarind tree which flanked a path running through the Town Hall Park. It was a remarkable place in many ways : a surging crowd was always moving up and down this narrow road morning till night. A variety of trades and occupations was represented all along its way : medicine sellers, sellers of stolen hardware and junk, magicians, and, above all, an auctioneer of cheap cloth, who created enough din all day to attract the whole town. Next to him in vociferousness came a vendor of fried groundnut, who gave his ware a fancy name each day, calling it тАЬBombay Ice-CreamтАЬ one day, and on the next тАЬDelhi Almond,тАЭ and on the third тАЬ RajaтАЩs DelicacyтАЭ and so on and so forth, and people flocked to him. A considerable portion of this crowd dallied before the astrologer too. The astrologer transacted his business by the light of a flare which crackled and smoked up above the groundnut heap nearby. Half the enchantment of the place was due to the fact that it did not have the benefit of municipal lighting. The place was lit up by shop lights. One or two had hissing gaslights, some had naked flares stuck on poles, some were lit up by old cycle lamps, and one or two, like the astrologerтАЩs, managed without lights of their own. It was a bewildering criss-cross of light rays and moving shadows. This suited the astrologer very well, for the simple reason that he had not in the least intended to be an astrologer when he began life; and he knew no more of what was going to happen to others than he knew what was going to happen to himself next minute. He was as much a stranger to the stars as were his innocent customers. Yet he said things which pleased and astonished everyone: that was more a matter of study, practice, and shrewd guesswork. All the same, it was as much an honest manтАЩs labour as any other, and he deserved the wages he carried home at the end of a day. He had left his village without any previous thought or plan. If he had continued there he would have carried on the work of his forefathers namely, tilling the land, living, marrying, and ripening in his cornfield and ancestral home. But that was not to be. He had to leave home without telling anyone, and he could not rest till he left it behind a couple of hundred miles. To a villager it is a great deal, as if an ocean flowed between.

He had a working analysis of mankindтАЩs troubles : marriage, money, and the tangles of human ties. Long practice had sharpened his perception. Within five minutes he understood what was wrong. He charged three pies per question, never opened his mouth till the other had spoken for at least ten minutes, which provided him enough stuff for a dozen answers and advices. When he told the person before him, gazing at his palm, тАЬIn many ways you are not getting the fullest results for your efforts,тАЭ nine out of ten were disposed to agree with him. Or he questioned : тАЬIs there any woman in your family, maybe even a distant relative, who is not well disposed towards you? тАЬ Or he gave an analysis of character : тАЬ Most of your troubles are due to your nature. How can you be otherwise with Saturn where he is? You have an impetuous nature and a rough exterior.тАЭ This endeared him to their hearts immediately, for even the mildest of us loves to think that he has a forbidding exterior.

The nuts vendor blew out his flare and rose to go home. This was a signal for the astrologer to bundle up too, since it left him in darkness except for a little shaft of green light which strayed in from somewhere and touched the ground before him. He picked up his cowrie shells and paraphernalia and was putting them back into his bag when the green shaft of light was blotted out; he looked up and saw a man standing before him. He sensed a possible client and said: тАЭYou look so careworn. It will do you good to sit down for a while and chat with me.тАЭ The other grumbled some reply vaguely. The astrologer pressed his invitation; whereupon the other thrust his palm under his nose, saying: тАЬYou call yourself an astrologer?тАЬ The astrologer felt challenged and said, tilting the otherтАЩs palm towards the green shaft of light: тАЬYours is a nature . . .тАЭ тАЬ Oh, stop that,тАЭ the other said. тАЬ Tell me something worth while. . . .тАЭ Our friend felt piqued. тАЬI charge only three pies perSoc per question, and what you get ought to be good enough for your money. . .тАЭ At this the other withdrew his arm, took out an anna, and flung it out to him, saying: тАЬ I have some questions to ask. If I prove you are bluffing, you must return that anna to me with interest.тАЭ тАЬIf you find my answers satisfactory, will you give me five rupees?тАЬ тАЬNo.тАЭ тАЬOr will you give me eight annas?тАЬ тАЬAll right, provided you give me twice as much if you are wrong,тАЭ said the stranger. This pact was accepted after a little further argument. The astrologer sent up a prayer to heaven as the other lit a cheroot. The astrologer caught a glimpse of his face by the matchlight. There was a pause as cars hooted on the road and jutka drivers swore at their horses, and the babble of the crowd agitated the semi-darkness of the park.

The other sat down, sucking his cheroot, puffing out, sat there ruthlessly. The astrologer felt very uncomfortable. тАЬHere, take your anna back. I am not used to such challenges. It is late for me today. . . .тАЭ He made preparations to bundle up. The other held his wrist and said : тАЬYou canтАЩt get out of it now. You dragged me in while I was passing.тАЭ The astrologer shivered in his grip ; and his voice shook and became faint. тАЬLeave me today. I will speak to you tomorrow.тАЭ The other thrust his palm in his face and said: тАЬChallenge is challenge. Go on.тАЭ The astrologer proceeded, with his throat drying up: тАЬThere is a woman . . .тАЭ тАЭStop,тАЭ said the other. тАЬI donтАЩt want all that. Shall I succeed in my present search or not ? Answer this and go. Otherwise I will not let you go till you disgorge all your coins.тАЭ The astrologer muttered a few incantations and replied : тАЬAll right. I will speak. But will you give me a rupee if what I say is convincing ? Otherwise I will not open my mouth, and you may do what you like.тАЭ After a good deal of haggling the other agreed. The astrologer said : тАЬYou were left for dead. Am I right? тАЬ тАЬAh, tell me more.тАЭ тАЬA knife has passed through you once ? тАЬ said the astrologer. тАЬGood fellow ! тАЬ He bared his chest to show the scar. тАЬWhat else? тАЬAnd then you were pushed into a well nearby in the field. You were left for dead.тАЭ тАЭI should have been dead if some passer-by had not chanced to peep into the well,тАЭ exclaimed the other, overwhelmed by enthusiasm. тАШWhen shall I get at him ? тАЬ he asked, clenching his fist. тАЬIn the next world,тАЭ answered the astrologer. тАЬHe died four months ago in a far off town. You will never see any more of him.тАЭ The other groaned on hearing it. The astrologer proceeded : тАЬGuru Nayak тАЬ тАЬYou know my name ! тАЬ the other said, taken aback. тАЭAs I know all other things. Guru Nayak, listen carefully to what I have to say. Your village is two dayтАЩs journey due north of this town. Take the next train and be gone. I see once again great danger to your life if you go from home.тАЭ He took out a pinch of sacred ash and held it to him. тАЬ Rub it on your forehead and go home. Never travel southward again, and you will live to be a hundred.тАЭ тАЬWhy should I leave home again ? тАЬ the other said reflectively. тАЬ I was only going away now and then to look for him and to choke out his life if I met him.тАЭ He shook his head regretfully. тАЬ He has escaped my hands. I hope at least he died as he deserved.тАЭ тАЬYes,тАЭ said the astrologer. тАЬ He was crushed under a lorry.тАЭ The other looked gratified to hear it.

The place was deserted by the time the astrologer picked up his articles and put them into his bag. The green shaft was also gone, leaving the place in darkness The stranger had gone off into the night, after giving the astrologer a handful of coins. It was nearly midnight when the astrologer reached home. His wife was waiting for him at the door and demanded an explanation. He flung the coins at her and said : тАЬ Count them. One man gave all that.тАЭ тАЭTwelve and a half annas,тАЭ she said, counting. She was overjoyed. тАЬ I can buy some jaggery and coconut tomorrow. The child has been asking for sweets for so many days now. I will prepare some nice stuff for her.тАЭ тАЬThe swine has cheated me ! He promised me a rupee,тАЭ said the astrologer. She looked up at him. тАЬYou look worried. What is wrong?тАЬ тАЬ Nothing.тАЭ After dinner, sitting on the pyol, he told her : тАЬDo you know a great load is gone from me today? I thought I had the blood of a man on my hands all these years. That was the reason why I ran away from home, settled here, and married you. He is alive.тАЭ She gasped. тАЬ You tried to kill! тАЬ тАЬYes, in our village, when I was a silly youngster. We drank, gambled, and quarrelled badly one day. Why think of it now ? Time to sleep,тАЭ he said, yawning, and stretched himself on the pyol.

english.title: Ode on a Grecian Urn
english.content:
Ode on a Grecian Urn

by John Keats

Thou still unravish'd bride of quietness,
Thou foster-child of silence and slow time,
Sylvan historian, who canst thus express
A flowery tale more sweetly than our rhyme:
What leaf-fring'd legend haunts about thy shape
Of deities or mortals, or of both,
In Tempe or the dales of Arcady?
What men or gods are these? What maidens loth?
What mad pursuit? What struggle to escape?
What pipes and timbrels? What wild ecstasy?

Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard
Are sweeter; therefore, ye soft pipes, play on;
Not to the sensual ear, but, more endear'd,
Pipe to the spirit ditties of no tone:
Fair youth, beneath the trees, thou canst not leave
Thy song, nor ever can those trees be bare;
Bold Lover, never, never canst thou kiss,
Though winning near the goalтАФyet, do not grieve;
She cannot fade, though thou hast not thy bliss,
For ever wilt thou love, and she be fair!

Ah, happy, happy boughs! that cannot shed
Your leaves, nor ever bid the Spring adieu;
And, happy melodist, unwearied,
For ever piping songs for ever new;
More happy love! more happy, happy love!
For ever warm and still to be enjoy'd,
For ever panting, and for ever young;
All breathing human passion far above,
That leaves a heart high-sorrowful and cloy'd,
A burning forehead, and a parching tongue.

Who are these coming to the sacrifice?
To what green altar, O mysterious priest,
Lead'st thou that heifer lowing at the skies,
And all her silken flanks with garlands drest?
What little town by river or sea-shore,
Or mountain-built with peaceful citadel,
Is emptied of this folk, this pious morn?
And, little town, thy streets for evermore
Will silent be; and not a soul to tell
Why thou art desolate, can e'er return.

O Attic shape! Fair attitude! with brede
Of marble men and maidens overwrought,
With forest branches and the trodden weed;
Thou, silent form, dost tease us out of thought
As doth eternity: Cold Pastoral!
When old age shall this generation waste,
Thou shalt remain, in midst of other woe
Than ours, a friend to man, to whom thou say'st,
"Beauty is truth, truth beauty,тАФthat is all
Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know."
